title: Apra PD 2023 Workshop
text:
Using Posit Cloud
The materials for this workshop are available in a cloud environment that can be run with no downloads or setup. If you plan to go this route, there is nothing else you need to do in preparation, simply scan the QR code or visit https://posit.cloud/content/6215314.

title: Apra PD 2023 Workshop
text:
Using a Local Installation
If you are a workshop attendee and have any trouble with installation locally, please reach out to me directly!

Install latest version of RStudio, 2023.06.0+421) or later
Ideally upgrade/use to R 4.3.1 (I‚Äôm using the magittr pipe %>%)
Install these R packages:


pkg_list <- c(
  "tidyverse", "tidytext", "wordcloud"
  )
install.packages(pkg_list)







Tip



If you are a workshop attendee who would like to use their own RStudio installation, please clone https://github.com/mattfarrow1/text-mining-workshop.git via RStudio on Monday morning (August 28).








How to clone a Github repo






Navigate to https://github.com/mattfarrow1/text-mining-workshop
Click on the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button and copy the url under the HTTPS tab https://github.com/mattfarrow1/text-mining-workshop.git
In RStudio, use File > New Project > Version Control > From Git > and then paste the URL into the source repo box and then click enter!










(Optional!) Pre-Work for Python





This will be a R/RStudio-centric course based on the attendees, but we will briefly cover other editors and Python. You are not required to install Jupyter/Python/VScode, but if you‚Äôd like to test them out:

Install Python, following instructions at Minimum Viable Python
Install Jupyter
Install VSCode, Quarto VSCode extension, Python VSCode extension, Jupyter VSCode extension

title: Apra PD 2023 Workshop
text:
Competencies







Primary
DS: Competency 3: Data Manipulation Skills


Auxiliary
DS: Competency 5: Visualization/Reporting Techniques and Competencies


Tertiary
DS: Competency 4: Statistical Techniques and Competencies

title: Apra PD 2023 Workshop
text:
Learning Objectives







Learning Objective 1
Attendees will create word counts and keyword searches in Excel.


Learning Objective 2
Attendees will also utilize R (possibly Python too) to work on advanced text mining including stop words, topic modeling, word clouds, and sentiment analysis.




These materials are developed for a trainer-led workshop at Apra PD 2023, but should be useful for self-guided learning as well.

title: Apra PD 2023 Workshop
text:
Instructor
Matt Farrow is the Director of Prospect Development and Strategy at Children‚Äôs Health. He previously worked as the Assistant Director of Prospect Management at Southern Methodist University, where he earned an M.S. degree in Data Science. Matt is passionate about helping people extract insights and wisdom from their data. He may also have a small problem with his love of LEGO.

 This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

title: Extracting Value from Free Text
text: Pandoc supports numbering and formatting footnotes using the following syntax:

title: Extracting Value from Free Text
text:
Output
Here is a footnote reference,1 and another.2
This paragraph won‚Äôt be part of the note, because it isn‚Äôt indented.

title: Extracting Value from Free Text
text:
Footnotes


Here is the footnote.‚Ü©Ô∏é
Here‚Äôs one with multiple blocks.
Subsequent paragraphs are indented to show that they belong to the previous footnote.
{ some.code }
The whole paragraph can be indented, or just the first line. In this way, multi-paragraph footnotes work like multi-paragraph list items.‚Ü©Ô∏é

df |> 
  ggplot(aes(Rating)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Ratings",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Count") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal()








df |> 
  ggplot(aes(Rating, fill = Park)) +
  geom_bar(color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Ratings by Park",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Count",
       fill = "Park") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  scale_fill_discrete() +
  theme_minimal()








df |> 
  ggplot(aes(Park, Rating, color = Park)) +
  geom_boxplot(color = "black") +
  geom_jitter(alpha = 0.3) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Ratings by Park",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()

Getting Started

# Install libraries
# install.packages("tidyverse")
# install.packages("tidytext")

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(tidytext)
library(wordcloud)

# Read in the data
df <- read_csv("DisneylandReviews.csv")

Examine the Data

# head(df)
# str(df)
glimpse(df)

Rows: 42,656
Columns: 6
$ Review_ID         <dbl> 670772142, 670682799, 670623270, 670607911, 67060729‚Ä¶
$ Rating            <dbl> 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 3, 5, 3, 2, 5, 5, 5, 4, 5, 5, 3, 4, 3‚Ä¶
$ Year_Month        <chr> "2019-4", "2019-5", "2019-4", "2019-4", "2019-4", "2‚Ä¶
$ Reviewer_Location <chr> "Australia", "Philippines", "United Arab Emirates", ‚Ä¶
$ Review_Text       <chr> "If you've ever been to Disneyland anywhere you'll f‚Ä¶
$ Branch            <chr> "Disneyland_HongKong", "Disneyland_HongKong", "Disne‚Ä¶

Look at the Parks

unique(df$Branch)

[1] "Disneyland_HongKong"   "Disneyland_California" "Disneyland_Paris"

Clean up Park Names

df <- df %>% 
  rename(Park = Branch) %>% 
  mutate(Park = recode(Park,
                       "Disneyland_California" = "California",
                       "Disneyland_HongKong" = "Hong Kong",
                       "Disneyland_Paris" = "Paris"
  ))

unique(df$Park)

[1] "Hong Kong"  "California" "Paris"

Examine the Data


df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(Rating)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Ratings",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Count") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal()

Examine the Data


df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(Rating, fill = Park)) +
  geom_bar(color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Ratings by Park",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Count",
       fill = "Park") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  scale_fill_discrete() +
  theme_minimal()

Examine the Data


df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(Park, Rating, color = Park)) +
  geom_boxplot(color = "black") +
  geom_jitter(alpha = 0.3) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Ratings by Park",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()

Sample Review


[1] "This place is HUGE! Definately need more than one day. We had 3 children aged 11, 9 & 6 and they loved it. A great variety of rides and attractions for all ages. Food options were fantastic with 3D models of what you were ordering. Staff were fantastic, very helpful. An awesome family experience."

Sample Review

# Convert it to a tibble
sample <- tibble(line = 1, text = df$Review_Text[15])
sample



# A tibble: 1 √ó 2
   line text                                                                    
  <dbl> <chr>                                                                   
1     1 This place is HUGE! Definately need more than one day. We had 3 childre‚Ä¶

Sample Review: Unnest Tokens

# Unnest tokens
tidy_sample <- sample %>% 
  unnest_tokens(word, text)
tidy_sample



# A tibble: 53 √ó 2
    line word      
   <dbl> <chr>     
 1     1 this      
 2     1 place     
 3     1 is        
 4     1 huge      
 5     1 definately
 6     1 need      
 7     1 more      
 8     1 than      
 9     1 one       
10     1 day       
# ‚Ñπ 43 more rows

Sample Review: Word Count

# Word count
tidy_sample %>% 
  count(word, sort = TRUE) %>% 
  head()



# A tibble: 6 √ó 2
  word          n
  <chr>     <int>
1 were          3
2 and           2
3 fantastic     2
4 of            2
5 11            1
6 3             1

section: Sample Review: Word Count w/o Stop Words
text:
Sample Review: Word Count w/o Stop Words

# Word count without stop words
tidy_sample %>% 
  filter(!word %in% stop_words$word) %>% 
  count(word, sort = TRUE) %>% 
  head()



# A tibble: 6 √ó 2
  word          n
  <chr>     <int>
1 fantastic     2
2 11            1
3 3             1
4 3d            1
5 6             1
6 9             1

Number Each Review

Word Clouds

N-Grams

A continuous sequence of n words
Can be used ‚Äòas is‚Äô, or run through a stemmer to get morphemes
Offers greater context than single words
Bigrams (prep)

Bigrams


# A tibble: 6 √ó 3
# Groups:   Park [3]
  Park       bigram                   n
  <chr>      <chr>                <int>
1 California fast pass             3123
2 Hong Kong  hong kong             3025
3 Paris      disneyland paris      2932
4 California california adventure  2293
5 Paris      fast pass             1940
6 California disney world          1926
Word & Document Frequencies

Sentiment Analysis
An introduction using the ‚Äòjoy‚Äô sentiment.


# A tibble: 6 √ó 2
  word          sentiment
  <chr>         <chr>    
1 absolution    joy      
2 abundance     joy      
3 abundant      joy      
4 accolade      joy      
5 accompaniment joy      
6 accomplish    joy

2 fun      9952
3 parade   8468

5 magical  5190

Introduction to Text Mining

Pros and Cons
Formulas
Using ChatGPT to help with formulas
Keyword Search
Word Count







Pros - Universally available - Not going anywhere - Low barrier to entry - Scales in complexity
:::
:::
Cons - Can be difficult to reproduce - Potentially destructive - Doesn‚Äôt scale well - Limited options for text mining
:::
::::



=VLOOKUP(Value to look up, Range to look for value, Column for the return value, Type of match)
=VLOOKUP(A1, Lookup!A1:B7, 2, TRUE)



Relative references can move.
A1
Absolute references can‚Äôt move.
$A$1




tbl <- tibble::tribble(
~`$A$2`, ~`The column and the row do not change when copied.`,
"A$2","The row does not change when copied.",
"$A2","The column does not change when copied."
)

kableExtra::kable_styling(knitr::kable(tbl), font_size = 24)




$A$2
The column and the row do not change when copied.




A$2
The row does not change when copied.


$A2
The column does not change when copied.










=COUNTIF(Where are we looking?, What are we looking for?)
=COUNTIF(A:A, ‚ÄúWashington‚Äù)









Warning



Assume that everything you put into ChatGPT (or other LLMs) is public. Do not enter confidential or proprietary information into it.


Tell ChatGPT what is is you need assistance with:
















Source: ChatGPT
=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)



=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)

Replace Keywords_Range with the actual range of keywords you want to search for. For example, if your keywords are in cells A1 to A10, the range would be A1:A10.




=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)

Replace Cell with the cell reference of the cell in the column you want to search. This is the cell where you want to check if any of the keywords are present. For example, if you want to search in column B, and the first cell is B2, you would use B2 as the cell reference.




Source: ChatGPT
=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)

Enter the formula in the cell where you want the search result to appear.

The formula will return ‚ÄúFound‚Äù if any of the keywords in the range are found in the specified cell, and ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù if none of the keywords are found.
Note: This formula is case-insensitive, so it will match keywords regardless of their case. If you want case-sensitive matching, you can use the FIND function instead of SEARCH in the formula.

Excel Agenda

Why Excel?

Universally available
Not going anywhere
Low barrier to entry

Cons

Can be difficult to reproduce
Potentially destructive
Doesn‚Äôt scale well

Formula: vlookup
=VLOOKUP(Value to look up, Range to look for value, Column for the return value, Type of match)
=VLOOKUP(A1, Lookup!A1:B7, 2, TRUE)

Formula: absolute/relative references
Relative references can move.
A1
Absolute references can‚Äôt move.
$A$1

Formula: absolute/relative references





$A$2
The column and the row do not change when copied.




A$2
The row does not change when copied.


$A2
The column does not change when copied.

Formula: countif
=COUNTIF(Where are we looking?, What are we looking for?)
=COUNTIF(A:A, ‚ÄúWashington‚Äù)

ChatGPT for Formula Help






Warning


Assume that everything you put into ChatGPT (or other LLMs) is public. Do not enter confidential or proprietary information into it.



Tell ChatGPT what is is you need assistance with:

Formula: keyword search
Source: ChatGPT

Formula: keyword search
=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)

Replace Keywords_Range with the actual range of keywords you want to search for. For example, if your keywords are in cells A1 to A10, the range would be A1:A10.

Formula: keyword search
=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)

Replace Cell with the cell reference of the cell in the column you want to search. This is the cell where you want to check if any of the keywords are present. For example, if you want to search in column B, and the first cell is B2, you would use B2 as the cell reference.

Formula: keyword search
Source: ChatGPT
=IF(SUMPRODUCT(‚ÄìISNUMBER(SEARCH(Keywords_Range, Cell)))>0, ‚ÄúFound‚Äù, ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù)

Enter the formula in the cell where you want the search result to appear.

The formula will return ‚ÄúFound‚Äù if any of the keywords in the range are found in the specified cell, and ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù if none of the keywords are found.
Note: This formula is case-insensitive, so it will match keywords regardless of their case. If you want case-sensitive matching, you can use the FIND function instead of SEARCH in the formula.

Into to Text Mining
Keyword searches in Excel
Getting started with R
Text mining in R
Text mining in Python




What do you think of when I say text mining?
How much experience do you have with coding languages like R or Python?
What types of things are you most interested in? (keywords, sentiment, ngrams, word clouds‚Ä¶)

Poll

What do you think of when I say text mining?
How much experience do you have with coding languages like R or Python?
What types of things are you most interested in? (keywords, sentiment, ngrams, word clouds‚Ä¶)

What is text mining?
Text mining is the process of extracting information and insights from unstructured text.

Terms to Know

Natural Language: A natural language, as opposed to an artificially created language such as R or Python, develops gradually and often without thought, over time. (Examples include English or Italian.)
Natural Language Processing (NLP): refers to the creation and use of computational power in order to process content in natural language.

Terms to Know

Segmentation/Tokenization: the process of splitting apart pieces of language. Sentence segmentation is the process of breaking sentences apart using tokenizers to examine punctuation, abbreviations, and capitalization. Word tokenization involves breaking out the individual words of a sentence.

Terms to Know

Text Normalization: involves standardizing text prior to analysis. Examples include the expansion of contractions (don‚Äôt -> do not), removal of stop words (of, and, it), correcting misspellings, and stemming (if required)

Terms to Know

Term Frequency: measures how often a term appears in a document.
Document Frequency: measures how often a term appears in a corpus of documents.

Terms to Know

Inverse Document Frequency: a number computed by dividing the total number of documents in the corpus by the number of documents containing the target term and applying a log scale.
TF-IDF: ‚ÄúTerm Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency‚Äù. Higher term frequency and a lower document frequency leads to a higher TF-IDF.

Levels of Analysis

Lexical Analysis: The most basic form of NLP, lexical analysis is focused on analyzing individual words.
Syntactic Analysis: concerned with processing the grammar of written words.
Semantic Analysis: builds on lexical and syntactic analyses in order to understand the meanings of words.
Discourse Analysis: Understanding inferences in language is the domain of discourse analysis.



Introduction to Text Mining

What is R?
R vs.¬†Python?


R is a programming language started by professors Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman as a programming language to teach introductory statistics at the University of Auckland. It was developed in the early 1990‚Äôs and open sourced in 1995.
For the purposes of this workshop, there are no significant differences in R vs.¬†Python other than the language and packages/libraries used. I chose to start with R because that‚Äôs where I‚Äôm most comfortable, it‚Äôs the language that I see Apra promoting, and the community is incredibly welcoming and diverse.










Tip



Everything in this workshop can be done through the virtual project. Scan the QR code to get started.




    

Discuss the layout of RStudio and what people are looking at.

What is R?
R vs.¬†Python?


R is a programming language started by professors Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman as a programming language to teach introductory statistics at the University of Auckland. It was developed in the early 1990‚Äôs and open sourced in 1995.
For the purposes of this workshop, there are no significant differences in R vs.¬†Python other than the language and packages/libraries used. I chose to start with R because that‚Äôs where I‚Äôm most comfortable, it‚Äôs the language that I see Apra promoting, and the community is incredibly welcoming and diverse.

Getting Started






Tip


Everything in this workshop can be done through the virtual project. Scan the QR code to get started.





    

Discuss the layout of RStudio and what people are looking at.

Packages

Libraries of code
Expand the ‚Äúbase R‚Äù code
For almost anything you need
Beware of relying too heavily on niche packages

The tidyverse






The tidyverse is an opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science. All packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures.

https://www.tidyverse.org

The tidyverse vs ‚ÄòBase R‚Äô







Source: dplyr base R

How does it work?

The tidyverse

What is it?
How does it work?

The tidyverse Benefits

Easier to understand for new users
Packages all work together
Can ‚Äúpipe‚Äù instructions together
Covers most frequent use cases

The tidyverse Packages







Source: RStudio Education

dplyr

mutate() create variables (columns)
select() subset variables
filter() subset observations (rows) based on criteria
summarise() reduces multiple observations down to a single summary
arrange() change the ordering of observations

tidymodels
Although it‚Äôs not the focus of this workshop, the tidymodels packages contains a similar collection of packages devoted to modeling that integrates with the tidyverse.

The Beset Benefit (in my opinion)



‚ÄúArtwork by @allison_horst.‚Äù

The Best Benefit (in my opinion)







‚ÄúArtwork by @allison_horst.‚Äù

Packages

Libraries of code
Expand the ‚Äúbase R‚Äù code
For almost anything you need
Beware of relying too heavily on niche packages

Installing and loading packages
# Install libraries
install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("palmerpenguins")

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

The Data
42,656 reviews from Disney California, Hong Kong, and Paris





Source: Kaggle

Why Choose Excel?


Pros

Universally available
Not going anywhere
Low barrier to entry
Scales in complexity


Cons

Can be difficult to reproduce
Potentially destructive
Doesn‚Äôt scale well
Limited options for text mining

Word Counts
=LEN(TRIM(A1))-LEN(SUBSTITUTE(A1," ",""))+1

LEN(A1) counts the total number of characters in A1
TRIM removes any leading, trailing, and extra spaces (except single spaces between words)
SUBSTITUTE(A1,‚Äù ‚Äú,‚Äù‚Äù) removes all spaces from the text
LEN(SUBSTITUTE(A1,‚Äù ‚Äú,‚Äú‚Äù) ‚Äì counts the total number of characters in the text that have no spaces
LEN(A1)-LEN(SUBSTITUTE(A1,‚Äù ‚Äú,‚Äú‚Äù)) subtracts the text length without spaces from the text length with spaces
=LEN(A1)-LEN(SUBSTITUTE(A1,‚Äù ‚Äú,‚Äú‚Äù))+1 add 1 to the result as the number of spaces is one less than the total number of words

VLOOKUP
=VLOOKUP(A1, '[WorkbookName.xlsx]SheetName'!A1:B10,2,FALSE)

A1 the value you are looking up
'[WorkbookName.xlsx]SheetName'!A1:B10 the range where you are looking for a match
2 the column the match is found in
FALSE indicates whether you want to match exactly (FALSE) or approximately (TRUE)

Absolute/Relative References

Relative references can move.
Absolute references can‚Äôt move.




Reference
Result When Copied




A2
The row and column both change


$A2
The column does not change


A$2
The row does not change


$A$2
Neither the row nor the column change

Keyword Searches
=IF(SUMPRODUCT(--ISNUMBER(SEARCH(keyword,A2)))>0,"Yes","No")

keyword is a named range of the words you are searching for
A2 is the cell in the column you‚Äôre searching in
SEARCH(keyword,A2) returns the start number of the found string as a number
ISNUMBER(SEARCH(keyword,A2)) converts items to either TRUE or FALSE
--ISNUMBER(SEARCH(keyword,A2)) coerces the TRUE and FALSE values to 1 and 0
SUMPRODUCT sums the 1‚Äôs and 0‚Äôs
IF(SUMPRODUCT...)>0,"Yes","No") if the result of SUMPRODUCT is greater than 1, then the formula returns ‚ÄúYes‚Äù (or any other result you want)

Why Visualize?

Gives us a sense of the data
See the distribution of the data
Raise questions to explore
Help shape your process

Ratings by Park
Here, we‚Äôve created a stacked bar chart showing the distribution of ratings by park.
Avg Ratings Over Time

df=df.sample(n=1000)

Examine a Review

df.loc[:,'Review_Text'].values[10]

'A very good once in a lifetime experience. Great parade with music and Disney characters. Many people so get here early. Also for the parade.'

Prep Data

# Convert to lowercase
df['Review_Text'] = df['Review_Text'].apply(lambda x : ' '.join(x.lower() for x in x.split()))
df['Review_Text'].head()

31092    disneyland is so beautiful and large.to see al...
28105    the lines for rides are too long. yes, the fas...
1121     loved hong kong disneyland although it is much...
17687    love disneyland! we are annual pass holders an...
23059    the california adventure park is much improved...
Name: Review_Text, dtype: object



# Remove punctuation
df['Review_Text'] = df['Review_Text'].str.replace('[^\w\s]', '')

Remove Stop Words

stop = stopwords.words('english')
df['Review_Text'] = df['Review_Text'].apply(lambda x : " ".join(x for x in x.split() if x not in stop))
df['Review_Text'].head()

31092    disneyland beautiful large.to see need stay le...
28105    lines rides long. yes, fast passes help little...
1121     loved hong kong disneyland although much small...
17687    love disneyland! annual pass holders love nost...
23059    california adventure park much improved additi...
Name: Review_Text, dtype: object

Lemmatizing

lemmatizer = WordNetLemmatizer()
df['Review_Text'] = df['Review_Text'].apply(lambda x : " ".join(lemmatizer.lemmatize(word) for word in x.split()))
df['Review_Text'].head()

31092    disneyland beautiful large.to see need stay le...
28105    line ride long. yes, fast pass help little sta...
1121     loved hong kong disneyland although much small...
17687    love disneyland! annual pas holder love nostal...
23059    california adventure park much improved additi...
Name: Review_Text, dtype: object

Most Common Words

most_common = Counter(' '.join(df['Review_Text']).split()).most_common(50)
most_common_df = pd.DataFrame(most_common, columns = ['Words', 'Freq'])
plt.figure(figsize = (15,7))
sns.barplot(data = most_common_df, x = 'Words', y = 'Freq')
plt.title('Most Common words')
plt.xticks(rotation = 60)
plt.show()

Word Cloud

word_index = Counter(" ".join(df['Review_Text']).split())
w_cloud = WordCloud(max_words = 1500, width = 800, height = 600).generate_from_frequencies(word_index, None)
plt.figure(figsize = (20,18))
plt.imshow(w_cloud)
plt.axis('off')
plt.show()
